Saul Ausländer.Action: Mumbles something to someone who talks to him, looks away and moves on without engaging.
Looks around at older people and children in the grove but does not interact with them.
Walks with determination and maintains a regular pace despite the surrounding distress.
Walks with determination, at a regular pace, lips tight, showing focus and control.
Glances cautiously around, observing his surroundings carefully.
Mumbles something when spoken to, then looks away and moves on without engaging.
Slows his pace to check on nearby people but does not engage with those staring at him.
Briefly looks to the side at kneeling, crying figures.
Keeps on walking quietly without engaging with people staring at him.
Leans and picks up a man's clothes on the ground after the man hesitates.
Advances quietly and observes the chaotic scene without engaging, showing restrained focus amidst confusion.
Keeps pace despite slowing down and others catching up; does not interact with others or assert himself.
Leans to pick up a man’s clothes after the man hesitates, showing attentiveness and willingness to assist in small practical ways.
Picks up a man's clothes from the ground and gathers more clothes lying around to put aside.
Stands silently in the corridor, face blank, not interacting with others amidst chaos and people suffering.
Helps two men struggling with a load, leans toward the ground to assist.
Tries to identify the source of a whimper, shows concern by freezing and focusing attention.
Follows Hirsch with his eyes as the boy is handled, but takes no further action in response to the boy’s suffering.
Hoses the ground mechanically and helps men struggling with a heavy load, showing focus and readiness to assist.
Tries to locate the source of a whimper and freezes upon seeing the injured boy, showing alertness but momentary hesitation.
Looks back at the boy's body with focused, attentive eyes and tries to speak in Yiddish to Feigenbaum, offering to do the task himself.
Does not intervene or object to the cold treatment and examination of the boy by the SS doctor.
Attempts to speak in broken Yiddish to Feigenbaum and volunteers to take responsibility for the body.
Observes the scene carefully, focusing intently on the boy's body after the SS doctor's examination.
Immediately returns to work when ordered by the SS guard without hesitation or confusion.
Carries the lifeless boy’s body carefully as if still alive.
Hesitates but respectfully asks the doctor not to cut the boy.
Seizes the body and carries it carefully and respectfully through the dangerous environment without hesitation.
Hesitates and stiffens visibly when confronted with medical instruments and the autopsy process, showing uncertainty.
Attempts to communicate in multiple languages (Yiddish, Hungarian) despite limitations, showing effort to navigate the situation.
Initially does not respond to Feigenbaum's question, showing silence which could be viewed as an omission in assertiveness or confidence.
Begins to plead with Miklos not to dissect the boy, expressing a desire to preserve the boy's body for a few hours, showing concern for the boy's dignity.
Nods hesitantly when Miklos questions if the boy is 'one of yours', demonstrating vulnerability and connection to the boy.
Does not look away from Miklos despite a tense situation, indicating sincerity and courage.
Covers the boy's body with a sheet after Miklos throws one on, showing respect and care for the deceased.
Remains inexpressive and silent at times, not actively engaging in conversation or asserting himself further.
Convinces Miklos to delay cutting the boy's body, negotiating a limited time to be alone with the body despite Miklos's skepticism.
Maintains steady eye contact with Miklos and does not back down despite tension, showing quiet confidence.
Nods and covers the body carefully after Miklos agrees, demonstrating thoughtful and deliberate behavior.
Fails to persuade Miklos beyond five minutes, accepts limitation without pushing further or exploring alternatives.
Leaves the room after minimal interaction, showing no attempt to further influence or advocate for his cause.
Kneels down and scrubs the floor along with other prisoners, showing shared effort and solidarity.
Engages in broken Yiddish conversation with others, attempting communication despite language barriers.
Offers to help Abraham quietly, indicating willingness to assist others.
Examines personal documents and pictures with care, showing respect for prisoners' identities.
Remains motionless and silent when Frankel throws personal papers into the fire, showing possible restraint or internal conflict.
Does not stop Yankl from taking documents, continues on his path silently.
Requests Frankel's help to bury a body and expresses desire for burial with prayers.
Does not stop Yankl when he forcefully takes the pile of documents and ignores his attempts to engage; quietly continues to Frankel.
Appears emotionally distant or withdrawn when Yankl speaks to him and does not respond to attempts to communicate.
Approaches Frankel with a clear request for help to bury a body and seeks assistance despite language difficulties.
Fails to know the prayer that Frankel mentions as necessary for burial ritual, indicating a gap in knowledge.
Keeps silent when Frankel asks the name, indicating possible reticence or mistrust.
Expresses anger saying 'It’s not enough' in broken Yiddish, showing sincerity and emotional investment.
Glances at Frankel during confrontation, possibly seeking connection or support.
Remains silent when Frankel asks for the prayer and the name, indicating restraint or uncertainty.
Responds in broken Yiddish angrily that 'It’s not enough', showing a determined and strong-willed stance despite limited communication skill.
Glances at Frankel and others during confrontation but does not escalate the conflict himself, showing awareness and composure under threat.
Allows Biederman to take control and intervene, not acting rashly or impulsively.
Asks Abraham for help quietly, admits he needs another rabbi, showing vulnerability and trust.
Sits down speechless after Abraham questions his request, showing humility.
Does not respond to Abraham’s ironic or questioning remarks, indicating restraint and respect.
Engages in whispered conversation with Abraham and Hirsch to identify the Greek man, shows concern and interest.
Pulls out bodies and drags them to the lift despite being hit and injured, continues helping others.
After Abraham advises him to stop talking to Biederman, Saul is suddenly idle and watches the men silently.
Asks targeted questions about the Greek man to Abraham and Hirsch in low voice demonstrating awareness and trying to gather precise information.
Efficiently pulls out bodies and carries them to the lift despite harsh and dangerous conditions.
Pauses and becomes idle after Abraham goes to Biederman, appearing uncertain or distracted.
Does not respond or retaliate after being hit by the Dutch SS guard, simply wiping off blood and continuing work.
Volunteers to help get a locksmith despite personal risk and limited language skills.
Volunteers to be the locksmith though uncertain, demonstrates initiative and relevant skills.
Struggles with language barriers but tries to communicate effectively.
Persuades others to let him take on a risky technical task despite doubts.
Ignores Abraham’s warning and follows Biederman willingly despite risks.
Accepts help from Biederman and follows him into dangerous area.
Insists he can be a locksmith and follows Biederman despite warnings, showing initiative and willingness to take action.
Puts the golden bracelet in his shoe for safekeeping, demonstrating foresight and practical skill.
Ignores Abraham's warning about being on his own, which could indicate recklessness or poor judgment.
Keeps watch cautiously while repairing the door, alert to surroundings and protecting others
Asks questions quietly but respectfully, showing concern without provoking
Stays observant but does not intervene in tense interactions between others
Pushes away Katz after Katz grabs his shirt.
Commands Katz to come out quietly, hides the camera to protect their operation.
Does not respond when shouted at; withdrawn behavior.
Speaks to a dark-faced man trying to identify him (Greek rabbi) despite language barrier.
Leaves Katz behind and joins Mietek's group, blending with diverse prisoners without hostility.
Closes his eyes briefly, showing a moment of internal reflection or seeking calm among harsh conditions.
Looks back at an SS guard who pushed him, engages with a young prisoner’s innocent gaze.
Moves decisively to join Mietek’s group, leaves Katz behind to do so, initiates conversation with another prisoner in broken Yiddish.
Looks around discreetly at men’s faces, tries to communicate despite language barrier.
Mechanically reacts to the violin notes without showing clear emotional or purposeful response.
Closes his eyes briefly during the truck ride, a moment of disengagement or reflection without visible active strategy.
Responds with a look to SS guard pushing his ribs but takes no visible action beyond that.
Tries to communicate quietly and sincerely with the Renegade, seeking his help for a dead child despite the danger and difficulty.
Silently observes the harsh treatment and environment but does not intervene or protest.
Manages to swap his position with another prisoner to be next to the Renegade, showing initiative and situational awareness.
Attempts to communicate covertly with the Renegade in broken Yiddish to enlist help for a dead, showing resourcefulness and focus despite the environment.
Looks around discreetly when SS guards shout, showing caution and situational awareness.
Does not escalate confrontation or provoke guards, maintaining a low profile which suggests careful behavior under pressure.
Takes the shovel away from the Renegade and acknowledges him as a rabbi, showing recognition and understanding.
Swims into dangerous waters under gunfire to save the drowning Renegade, risking his own life.
Keeps the dying Renegade's head above water and comforts him with a plea for forgiveness.
Speaks up to explain the situation for the renegade despite the risk.
Keeps silent and disoriented when insulted by Mietek.
Volunteers to speak Hungarian to explain the situation to the German officers and the interpreter kapo, demonstrating ability to communicate under pressure.
Responds clearly and directly when asked about the shovel, providing relevant information succinctly.
Endures physical abuse without losing composure or failing to carry out necessary communication.
Despite being soaked and exhausted, tries to maintain presence and respond accurately, showing situational awareness.
Is pushed to the ground and treated violently but does not resist or escalate the situation, which may reflect restraint but also potential passivity.
Does not verbally answer Mietek’s aggressive question and appears disoriented, suggesting possible momentary loss of focus.
Does not respond to Mietek's aggressive questioning and complies without resistance.
Stands still as a prisoner takes a bite of his apple; keeps looking at the man who took the apple.
Stands still while another prisoner takes a piece of apple from his pocket without objection.
Keeps observing the situation carefully as the groups are violently separated and beaten, showing situational awareness.
Moves with Mietek’s kommando towards the crematorium and interacts with Biederman and Abraham, indicating integration and communication within his group.
Fails to find the Greek prisoner that Abraham asked about, showing a potential inability to fulfill a key task.
Refuses Abraham’s offer to accompany him, insisting he will be right back, then moves quickly and discreetly to another room to work alone.
Attempts to communicate with the SS officers through pantomime and tries to maintain composure despite mockery.
Ignores the taunting and laughter of the SS officers without retaliation or animosity.
Does not confront or argue when the night kapo and foreman dismiss him, instead leaves silently.
Urgently searches the storage area and tunnel for something important, showing dedication and care for his comrades.
After being pushed back menacingly, Saul jumps onto the lift platform and searches frantically through corpses despite the risk and others' warnings.
Stares hypnotized at the bodies vanishing in fire, showing deep emotional engagement and possible sorrow.
Sits at the table with other prisoners, tense and silent while others eat and drink, showing withdrawal or reservedness in social setting.
Runs down stairs and searches urgently for something among Sonderkommando tools and clothes.
Jumps onto the lift platform moving upwards amid corpses despite warnings from fellow prisoner.
Stops and stares hypnotized at the burning bodies, showing emotional disturbance.
Sits among drunken and exhausted prisoners, facing food tensely and not engaging in communal eating or drinking.

Looks at Frankel with a strange look but does not engage, takes a piece of bread and then throws it onto the table, does not react verbally or physically when Hirsch demands valuables and hits him, remains silent and subdued.
Throws piece of bread on the table instead of eating it, remains silent and does not react to Hirsch's demand or Abraham's concern.
Keeps valuables hidden despite pressure from Hirsch and others, showing control over what he reveals.
Swiftly stands up and grabs Miklos to find out about the boy, showing urgent concern.
Asks Miklos if the boy can be exchanged for someone else, trying to protect the boy at personal risk.
Hesitates after Miklos reveals he hid the boy from doctors, showing internal conflict and care.
Swiftly stands up and confronts Miklos, grabbing his gown to get urgent information about the boy.
Drags Miklos to a quiet corner to speak privately despite tense circumstances.
Hesitates when Miklos reveals the boy is safe and cannot be exchanged, showing uncertainty.
Follows Miklos to the autopsy room and proceeds as instructed calmly and without hesitation.
Sits quietly next to the boy’s corpse, touches his hair gently, stays with him alone in the room
Wraps the boy’s body carefully, carries it on his shoulders covered by his jacket
Does not respond to Feigenbaum’s questions and pushes him away when he tries to uncover the body
Silently and carefully unwraps the sheet from the boy's corpse, handles the body with care, and covers it with his jacket to carry it out without drawing attention.
Does not respond verbally to Feigenbaum's questions and warnings, but physically pushes him away to proceed with his task.
Hurries through restricted areas carrying a suspicious load, showing some risk-taking but also determination and awareness.
Lays the body of the boy respectfully on the bed-camp and sits beside him quietly.
Expresses skepticism towards Abraham's promise to get a rabbi, showing distrust.
Acknowledges his basic need to eat despite tension and exhaustion, showing self-care and engagement.
Appears tired and somewhat isolated at the table, others ignore or look speechless at him.
Lays the boy's body carefully on a bed-camp and sits quietly in a corner.
Questions Abraham somewhat skeptically about the plan and the rabbi but continues engaging nonetheless.
Appears tired, disengaged, and rubs his temple, stopping eating as others talk around him.
Expresses doubt about Abraham's intentions and honesty.
Looks worried when Vassili questions his skills, not deflecting or boasting.
Moves away from the window when the SS officer shouts, avoids confrontation.
Cleans up the chaotic table methodically as ordered without complaint.
Stands clueless when designated by Voss, showing no hostility or resentment.
Continues cleaning despite the difficult and gruesome environment, hesitates when uncovering the revolver, indicating internal conflict.
Obeys orders to fetch Schlojme for Voss, quickly responds even though burdened with dishes.
Attempts to communicate respectfully with kapo Schlojme, uses a formal tone in Yiddish.
Does not resist or retaliate when violently beaten by the foreman, remains silent and submits to inhuman pace and harsh treatment.
Refuses to go with Abraham and Biederman despite pressure.
Answers Mandel’s question about the girl’s name sincerely.
Avoids Ella’s eyes despite her happy spark, showing emotional distance or restraint.

Successfully navigates entry into a guarded warehouse by complying with instructions and interacting with the female kapo Mandel, showing calm and purposeful movement through a highly controlled environment.
Avoids eye contact with Ella despite her showing a friendly spark in her eyes, possibly indicating emotional restraint or internal conflict rather than full social or emotional engagement.
Pushes away Ella’s attempt to take his hand despite her supportive gesture.
Leaves Ella and goes outside when neighbors get involved, avoiding emotional connection.
Pushes away Ella's hand, avoids emotional connection, but calmly handles a risky item from her and fixes it securely under his shirt with a belt.
Responds irritated but confidently to Landesman's question with a clear 'Yes', showing awareness and control.
Moves rapidly and abruptly changes group affiliation, joining a different group with lowered head, showing quick situational adaptation.
Avoids direct eye contact and emotional engagement, which could be seen as detachment or hesitation.
Leaves a tense confrontation by going outside quickly, potentially to avoid escalation or suspicion.
Inquires gently if a man is a rabbi, attempts to make contact by speaking in broken Yiddish
Pushes back young woman trying to talk to him, causing her to stumble
Touches the rabbi's arm and whispers to him to come, trying to connect and guide him
Turns his back on Braun and escapes when Braun tries to talk to him.
Touches the rabbi’s shoulder and gives him a jacket he picked up.
Shakes his head to the Kapo and does not talk to anyone as ordered.
Attempts to get closer to the rabbi among the crowd, following reluctantly like the civilians.
Converses briefly with Schlojme in broken Yiddish, attempting some friendly connection despite harsh circumstances.
Takes Schlojme’s arm and pushes the rabbi along, trying to intervene with the SS officer.
Gives his jacket and shirt to a man peering out of the darkness.
Shouts 'Sonderkommando' to the SS guard to try to save himself and others.
Attempts to communicate with the SS officer to protect or help Schlojme, showing initiative.
Falls to the ground after the officer pushes him aside, unable to maintain presence or control in chaotic moment.
Gives his Sonderkommando jacket and shirt to another man peering out from darkness, demonstrating quick thinking and self-sacrifice.
Looks for the right clothes amidst chaos but is ultimately grabbed and pushed into the line, unable to escape or influence outcome.
Shouts 'Sonderkommando' in German trying to gain the guard's attention, but the guard ignores him.
After rescuing a man he saved, Saul takes him to the woods and asks for help to bury his son, carefully wrapping the man's face and arm.
Looks around helplessly at the condemned people before his turn, showing empathy toward their fate.
Does not respond with anger or hostility when Mietek calls him 'vermin', instead calmly identifying himself and complying.
Quickly dresses up in stolen clothes and escapes from the line, showing situational awareness and decisiveness.
Takes the risk of moving a wounded man to the woods unnoticed, demonstrating courage and resourcefulness.
Calmly prepares the wounded man with care, indicating emotional steadiness and skill in handling difficult circumstances.
Looks around helplessly as people disappear into the trench, showing lack of immediate control over the situation.
Appears uncertain and hesitates before being taken out of the line, indicating some passivity in a critical moment.
Brings the rabbi to the crematorium for the dead, showing concern for the deceased's dignity.
Responds minimally to Frankel’s statement and does not engage much in conversation.
Communicates information about the man from Krema II to Schlojme despite language barriers.
Responds calmly when Frankel questions why he brought the rabbi, providing a clear purpose ('For the dead').
Shows little verbal engagement with Frankel after his statement about carrying the dead themselves; remains silent.
Hides and cares for the boy, gently cleans the body, puts water beside him, smiles tenderly.
Keeps Braun asleep to avoid disturbance, cautiously manages his interactions with Abraham.
Shows confusion and avoids confrontation about the lost powder package.
Hides a boy carefully under a sheet and tends to the body with delicate gestures, showing attention and care.
Looks confused and unaware about the fallen package of powder needed for their plan.
Communicates calmly and tries to reassure Abraham about future help despite the setback.
Protects and covers the body of the dead man tenderly, insisting he must bury his son properly.
Shows care and attention by shaving Braun’s face despite Braun’s coldness.
Does not react aggressively when beaten by Vassili, instead focusing on his purpose.
Points out Braun will do what is right, implying a trust or hope in another’s integrity.
Insists on a dignified burial despite others’ disbelief and opposition.
Stands up after being punched and continues with his task of covering the body despite physical violence.
Claims the deceased as his son and insists on burying him properly, demonstrating resolve and purpose.
Uses a razor to shave Braun quietly and carefully, suggesting practical skill and control.
Continuing to dig with Braun under watchful conditions, showing steady perseverance under pressure.
Allows himself to be hit without defending aggressively or attempting to deescalate, possibly indicating passivity or inability to alter the situation.
Deceptively claims a son he does not have, which could be seen as a strategic lie but also a risky emotional choice.
Ignores Feigenbaum’s warning and continues digging in his spot.
Pushes other prisoners aside to look for Braun in a crowded, tense situation.
Continues to dig despite Feigenbaum warning him not to; does not understand Yiddish, which hinders communication.
Pushes through a crowded, tense room looking for Braun, actively trying to find an ally or acquaintance.
Intervenes when Braun is being harassed, telling others to leave him alone and physically helping Braun by lifting him up.
Expresses personal vulnerability by revealing he has to take care of his son and reveals son's complex parentage, showing sincerity and openness.
Attempts to stand tall and assert himself despite hostile and indifferent environment.
Engages with others quietly and without provoking, but encounters cold and unsupportive reactions, showing his tolerant attempts at communication.
Looks at Abraham after Biederman is taken away but does not speak or react, seemingly overwhelmed and weary.
Observes the men in the courtyard with weariness, does not visibly engage or offer comfort.
Looks for Braun amid chaos and goes with the flow toward the exit, indicating concern for others and awareness of the situation.
Allows himself to be seized by Vassili and taken along without resistance, showing tolerance or resigned compliance rather than hostility.
Despite chaos and danger, helps Braun carry the corpse and urges him to follow and escape together.
Stops to dig a grave and asks Braun to say Kaddish, showing care for the proper burial and respect for the dead.
Does not let Braun rest during their escape, pushing him relentlessly.
Rushes out into confusion and danger, navigates chaotic situation confidently, finds Braun and takes charge by guiding him to escape.
Stops abruptly in the woods and starts digging frantically with his hands despite exhaustion and imminent threat, insisting on performing a ritual for the corpse.
Shows some disregard for his own and Braun’s safety by stopping to dig during a pursuit, potentially risking both.
Attempts to save the corpse of the boy by carrying it through the water despite physical danger.
Calls for Braun to help him, showing trust and a desire for cooperation.
Watches helplessly as the body is lost and allows himself to be rescued without resistance, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Takes initiative to follow Braun while carrying the corpse, attempts to stop Braun and retrieves the body from the river despite danger.
Fails to save the corpse from being swept away by the river and almost drowns, shows helplessness and exhaustion.
Stands still and silent while others attend to wounded and discuss plans, shows no interaction with the boy or others at critical moments.
Looks up at the boy who approaches and observes him calmly, without hostility.
Stands still and silent when confronted by a situation with other fugitives debating plans, showing no initiative or leadership.
Looks up at the boy who examines the men calmly without panic, maintaining composure in a tense moment.
Does not engage or contribute to the group's planning or in responding effectively to the threat of the SS squad.

Braun.Action: Runs away and abandons Saul despite his call for help, ignoring comradeship.
